headline.main: The Enron Inquiry: Lessons From a Collapse

docs.snippet: In Tony Kushner's new play ''Homebody/Kabul,'' Linda Emond plays the Homebody, a middle-aged Englishwoman, who is sitting in a comfortable chair in her London home, reading a slender book when the lights come up. Mr. Kushner wrote the play, now at...
docs.lead_paragraph: In Tony Kushner's new play ''Homebody/Kabul,'' Linda Emond plays the Homebody, a middle-aged Englishwoman, who is sitting in a comfortable chair in her London home, reading a slender book when the lights come up. Mr. Kushner wrote the play, now at the New York Theater Workshop in the East Village, before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and the action takes place in 1998. These excerpts are from Ms. Emond's opening monologue. ''Our story begins at the very dawn of history, circa 3000 B.C. . . .''
docs.abstract: Excerpts from actress Linda Emond's opening monologue as character Homebody in Tony Kushner's new play Homebody/Kabul, at New York Theater Workshop; photo (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The Enron debacle is the logical culmination of a system that increasingly favors corporate management over shareholders (''Enron Buffed Image to a Shine Even as It Rotted From Within,'' front page, Feb. 10).     There have been ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Enron debacle is the logical culmination of a system that increasingly favors corporate management over shareholders (''Enron Buffed Image to a Shine Even as It Rotted From Within,'' front page, Feb. 10). There have been past signs of trouble brewing, like the stratospheric rise in executive salaries and stock options. It should come as no surprise that something resembling a Rube Goldberg contraption would be constructed by managers whose frenzied desire to enrich themselves exceeded their capacity to do so ethically or sensibly.
docs.abstract: Letter from David Katcoff says Enron debacle is logical culmination of system that increasingly favors corporate management over shareholders

headline.main: Let's Make Enron a Turning Point

docs.snippet: An Islamic cleric who was praised by Al Qaeda and censured by the Saudi government, Sheik Hammoud bin Oqla al-Shoeiby, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 77.    Sheik al-Shoeiby rose to become a leading Islamic scholar in Saudi Arabia. His st...
docs.lead_paragraph: An Islamic cleric who was praised by Al Qaeda and censured by the Saudi government, Sheik Hammoud bin Oqla al-Shoeiby, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 77. Sheik al-Shoeiby rose to become a leading Islamic scholar in Saudi Arabia. His students included the country's mufti, the current minister of justice and a former Islamic affairs minister.
docs.abstract: Sheik Hammoud bin Oqla al-Shoeiby, Islamic cleric who was praised by Al Qaeda and censured by Saudi government, dies at age 77 (S)

docs.snippet: BROWN-Kenneth Ridgeway, 77. On March 19, 2002 in Toronto, Canada. Born in Newcastle, England, graduated from the Durham School and University of London (engineering). Served in the Royal Navy during World War II on aircraft carrier HMS Battler in ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BROWN-Kenneth Ridgeway, 77. On March 19, 2002 in Toronto, Canada. Born in Newcastle, England, graduated from the Durham School and University of London (engineering). Served in the Royal Navy during World War II on aircraft carrier HMS Battler in the North Atlantic. Immigrated to Canada in 1954 during 36 year career with The General Electric Company PLC. CEO of English Electric Corp. in New York for 9 years until his retirement in 1983. Member of several boards of directors. Survived by his wife Diane of 47 years, sister Ann (Bridges), sons Christopher, Graeme and David, daughter-in-law, Anne, grandsons Trevor and Derek. A memorial service to celebrate Kenneth Brown's life will be held in Bracebridge, Ontario in June.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  Brown, Kenneth Ridgeway

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Nicholas D. Kristof is right that the Bush administration's decision to train Yemen's military to fight Al Qaeda is well intentioned but problematic (column, March 19). I worked in Yemen promoting democracy for an American organi...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof is right that the Bush administration's decision to train Yemen's military to fight Al Qaeda is well intentioned but problematic (column, March 19). I worked in Yemen promoting democracy for an American organization and visited some of the villages mentioned. The people have little hope, a product of poverty and powerlessness. Mr. Kristof says many people have more loyalty to local leaders than to the central government. That is because local leaders are often the only ones providing basic necessities.
docs.abstract: David Nassar letter on Nicholas D Kristof's Mar 19 column agrees Bush administration's decision to train Yemen's military to fight Al Qaeda is problematic

docs.snippet: WHEN Switzerland finally took the plunge and voted last week to join the United Nations, was it the end of neutrality as we know it? On the contrary, said Ambassador Jenö C. A. Staehelin, who has been the Swiss ''permanent observer'' at the Unite...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Switzerland finally took the plunge and voted last week to join the United Nations, was it the end of neutrality as we know it? On the contrary, said Ambassador Jenö C. A. Staehelin, who has been the Swiss ''permanent observer'' at the United Nations since 1997. The move may give neutrality a lift. In return for supporting United Nations membership, Swiss voters were promised that Switzerland would enter the organization as a ''neutral country,'' he said, and that's what the government's letter of application says.
docs.abstract: Switzerland, whose voters have approved bid to join United Nations, will be joining small group of formally neutral countries; Amb Jeno C A Staehelin, who campaigned for membership, holds UN itself is neutral; photo (M)

headline.main: The World; The Swiss Taking Sides? Not So Fast

docs.snippet: YOUNG-John P. On January 23, 2002. Married for 57 years to his beloved Ruth. Devoted father of Patricia, Pamela and Bill. Cherished father-in-law of Marie and the late Kevin Mahon. Adored by his ''M&Ms,'' his granddaughters, Meghan & Marissa. Dear...
docs.lead_paragraph: YOUNG-John P. On January 23, 2002. Married for 57 years to his beloved Ruth. Devoted father of Patricia, Pamela and Bill. Cherished father-in-law of Marie and the late Kevin Mahon. Adored by his ''M&Ms,'' his granddaughters, Meghan & Marissa. Dear brother of Thomas and the late Robert and Edward. He served his nation as a pilot in World War II and the Korean Conflict and retired as a Colonel USAF. He was the founder of Capitol Agency, a respected painter and artist, and, above all else, matchless in his courage in the face of long and debilitating illness. He will forever be in the hearts of his family and friends. Family requests that, in lieu of flowers or other tributes, that donations be made in his memory to your local American Heart Association. Funeral Mass was at St. Patrick's and interment in St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, CT, on Saturday, the 26th of January.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, JOHN P.

docs.snippet: FINCH-Edward E. Age 77, resident of Rockville Centre, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. died on January 18, 2002. Survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Mildred. Devoted father of Raymond, Jack, Dan, Julie, Florence, Ed and Liz. Cherished ''Pop'' o...
docs.lead_paragraph: FINCH-Edward E. Age 77, resident of Rockville Centre, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. died on January 18, 2002. Survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Mildred. Devoted father of Raymond, Jack, Dan, Julie, Florence, Ed and Liz. Cherished ''Pop'' of thirteen grandchildren. Ed was born and raised in New York City. He served in World War II as a navigator on C47's and retired as a Lieutenant Colonel in the United States Airforce, Irongate Squardron. Graduated from New York University with a Bachelor of Science degree. Considered the ''original prize guy'', Ed started and help build an industry that specializes in promotional advertising on television. We love him and will miss his strength and support. A memorial Mass will be held at 10 AM at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre on January 26th.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, EDWARD E.
